title: Name
description: You can search for cards by name with 'name:' or by simply entering the words you want to find. By default, each word will be treated as a separate search token. Enclosing the string in quotes will cause it to be treated as a single token.

title: Description
description: You can search for cards by description with 'description:' or 'd:'. Multiple description queries, e.g. 'description:something description:other' can be used to narrow down the description, or a specific string can be enclosed in double quotes.

title: Attack, health or cost
description: You can search for cards by attack with any of the following operators: <, <=, =, >, >=.

title: Card Type
description: You can search for cards by type with 'type:' or 't:'. The values that work are: unit, spell, landmark, ability, equipment

title: Rarity
description: You can search for cards by rarity with 'rarity:' or 'r:'. The values that work are: common, rare, epic, champion, none

title: Region
description: You can search for cards by region with 'region:' or 'reg:'. The following regions work: Ionia, Noxus, Piltover and Zaun, Freljord, Bandle City, Bilgewater, Shadow Isles, Shurima, Targon, Runeterra

title: Keywords
description: You can search for cards by keywords with 'keyword:' or 'k:'. Multiple keyword queries can be separated by a comma to specify any of multiple keywords.

title: Format
description: You can search for cards by format with 'format:' or 'f:'. Multiple format queries can be separated by a comma to specify any of multiple formats. The following formats are legal: standard, eternal, commons only

title: Set
description: You can search for cards by set with 'set:' or 's:'. The lists of sets that are viable are: set1, set2, set3, set4, set5, set6, set6cde, set7, set7b, set8, set9

title: Flavor Text
description: You can search for cards by flavor text with 'flavor_text:' or 'ft:'.

title: Artist
description: You can search for cards by artist with 'artist:' or 'a:'.

title: OR operator
description: By default, all search queries are going to be combined together. To create a new set of queries, you can use the OR operator.
